Key Match Events: The Wolves committed just one turnover in the first quarter and jumped out to an early 13 point lead.
The Blazers ramped up their ball pressure, causing the Wolves to struggle with executing the offense and making basic passes.
The Wolves had seven of their 13 turnovers in the second quarter alone.
Portland scored 21 points off of the Wolves' 14 turnovers, while Minnesota scored just 12 points off of Portland's 20 turnovers.
The Wolves finished the game shooting 7-39 from three-point range, which is 17 percent.
Donovan Clingan recorded eight blocks during the game.
Donte DiVincenzo had a tough game, shooting 1-10 from the field and 0-6 from three, finishing with a minus eight rating.
Rob Dillingham saw his first meaningful regular season minutes and played well, showing a pass-first mindset and scrappy defense.
Post-Match Reflections: Head Coach Chris Finch commented on the team's shooting woes, stating, 'We couldn’t make a shot all night, and they threw in some timely ones.'
Finch also reflected on the rough patch the team is going through, saying, 'It’s a rough patch. It’s early on.'
Finch praised Rob Dillingham's performance, saying, 'I thought he came in and gave us really good minutes. It was a good first showing for sure.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: There is criticism on the coaching staff, but the article defends Head Coach Chris Finch and his top assistant Micah Nori.
Rudy Gobert had a lackluster performance in terms of rim protection and running the floor.
The Wolves are still in November and expected to have some rough stretches early in the season.
Others: The Wolves' next game is against the Sacramento Kings on Friday, November 15 at 9:00pm CT, which will be their second game in the NBA Cup group stage.
